channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Investigations Face a Dilemma Before the Midterm Elections
item.description: Justice Department officials are debating how an unwritten rule should affect the criminal investigations into Jan. 6 and the former president’s handling of sensitive documents.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Despite its name, the Justice Department’s 60-day rule is a general principle rather than a written law or regulation.

item.title: Republicans Seek Path for Constitutional Convention
item.description: A new book by a former Democratic senator warns of the risks of allowing states to call for a convention. Some in the G.O.P. see it as the only way to rein in the federal government.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Conservative Republicans in Congress are seeking to clear a path for a constitutional convention.

item.title: As Russia Chokes Europe’s Gas, France Enters Era of Energy ‘Sobriety’
item.description: The government is helping residents with soaring gas and electric costs, but some businesses are already shutting down amid fears of rationing and blackouts.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Filip Singer/European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: A Paris street. Some French cities plan to turn off streetlamps to conserve energy in winter.

item.title: Europe’s Leaders Vow Economic Relief, Fearing Unrest
item.description: Germany, Sweden and the Czech Republic announced measures to populations feeling the bite of rising inflation and energy costs tied to war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Martin Divisek/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A protest in Prague on Saturday against the Czech government and its response to the energy crisis.

item.title: Ukrainians in Rural Ireland Piece Together New Lives, Step by Step
item.description: With 50,000 Ukrainians now finding sanctuary in Ireland, the largest number of refugees the country has ever accepted is merging with locals in homogeneous rural villages.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian woman minding a child at a hostel that hosts Ukrainian families on Arranmore Island, Ireland.

item.title: Climate Change Is Ravaging the Colorado River. There’s a Model to Avert the Worst.
item.description: Success in the Yakima River Basin in Washington holds lessons for the seven states at war over water in the American West.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain and Ruth Fremson

item.title: In Montauk, Big Money Moves In on a Surfers’ Paradise
item.description: The acres overlooking a prize stretch of Long Island’s East End were empty for years. Now they’ve been sold in multimillion-dollar deals. It’s been the talk of the beach all summer.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Kenyon Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Surfers at Ditch Plains Beach, a part of Montauk known for its consistent waves.

item.title: How Justin Tucker Became the Greatest Kicker in N.F.L. History
item.description: The confidence, persistence, and all-out obsession required to play the least understood position on the field.
item.dc:creator: Wil S. Hylton
item.media:credit: Philip Montgomery for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justin Tucker at a preseason game against the Tennessee Titans in Baltimore.

item.title: China Imposes More Covid Lockdowns, Stoking Anxiety
item.description: Nearly every province has recorded infections in recent days, leaving some 60 million residents locked down. Weariness is growing by the day as the restrictions go on seemingly without end.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A testing site in Chengdu, China, on Friday, during a lockdown. The city’s testing system collapsed over the weekend, leaving residents waiting in line for hours.

item.title: George Clooney and Julia Roberts on ‘Ticket to Paradise’
item.description: For their latest big-screen partnership, they play exes who take shots at each other. It’s not such a stretch to the fond insults they sling in real life.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Biden Shouldn’t Apologize to Republicans
item.description: The president said that Trumpism resembles “semi-fascism.” He’s right.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times

item.title: Abortion and Trump Are Giving Democrats a Shot
item.description: This may be the year when politics gets flipped on its head.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: My Hopes and Fears for My Children as They Go Back to School
item.description: When I sent my kids back to school this year, I sent them with my prayers.
item.dc:creator: Tish Harrison Warren
item.media:credit: Matija Medved

item.title: Even With Biden as a Pro-Labor Champion, Unionizing Is Still a Grind
item.description: A flurry of new organizing efforts is giving young people hope. But even with a champion in the White House, unionizing is still a grind.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman

item.title: Student Journalists Reveal a Changing World. Let Them.
item.description: The shutdown of a high school newspaper in Nebraska is only the latest episode in efforts to censor student publications across red states.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Care
item.description: It can be a safe haven for our most vulnerable children.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; Jordan Rowland and the New York Public Library, via Unsplash; and Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: How Cesar Chavez’s Union Lost Its Way
item.description: Workers have to be persuaded that to join a union is worth the risk.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Pawel
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A statue of Cesar Chavez in San Fernando, Calif.

item.title: The Way You Get Around New York City by Bus and Train Is About to Change
item.description: The city’s crumbling infrastructure is finally getting some upgrades.
item.dc:creator: Mara Gay and Timothy Mulcare

item.title: The Fall Dining Scene
item.description: Diners are returning from their summer vacations and heading back into restaurants.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna
item.media:credit: Alexei Vella

item.title: Where to Host Your Birthday in NYC
item.description: Here’s where to host a group birthday dinner, whether it’s a park hang or an all-out fete.
item.dc:creator: Becky Hughes
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nothing screams “festivities” quite like a Dungeness crab on a lazy susan (especially this one at Wu’s Wonton King).

item.title: What Is a ‘Fake’ Artist in 2022?
item.description: Firestorms over the “virtual rapper” FN Meka and faceless artists on Spotify have sparked conversations about alienation and creative agency.

item.title: Americans Think Our Democracy Is on the Brink. So Does Biden.
item.description: We examine the president’s speech in Philadelphia with Zolan Kanno-Youngs, a White House reporter.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden laid out his concerns about American democracy with a prime-time address on Thursday in Philadelphia.

item.title: For Mark Spitz, Olympic Greatness Came Amid Tragedy
item.description: The former swimmer said it was “like an out-of-body experience” to win seven gold medals at the 1972 Munich Games and then learn that terrorists had attacked Israelis at the Olympic Village.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:credit: Hana Asano for The New York Times

item.title: Chile Voters Reject New, Left-Leaning Constitution
item.description: The rejected constitution would have legalized abortion, adopted universal health care and enshrined more than 100 constitutional rights, a global record.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating the rejection of the proposed constitution in Santiago, Chile, on Sunday.

item.title: What Is Labor Day? A History of the Workers’ Holiday.
item.description: President Grover Cleveland made it a national holiday in 1894, during a crisis over federal efforts to end a strike by railroad workers.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Library of Congress
item.media:description: A Labor Day parade on Main Street in Buffalo in 1900. President Grover Cleveland made Labor Day a national holiday in June 1894, as he faced a crisis of railway workers striking in Chicago.

item.title: LIV Golf Continues to Try New Ways to Be Noticed
item.description: Whether it’s the team concept or a decision to allow its golfers to play in shorts, the breakaway Saudi-backed series so far sees itself as the anti-PGA Tour.
item.dc:creator: Bill Pennington
item.media:credit: Richard Cashin/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Greg Norman landed by parachute during the first round of the LIV Golf tournament on Friday at The International in Bolton, Mass.

item.title: Why Is Pickleball So Popular?
item.description: Everyone and their mother seems to be playing. What’s the draw — and is it really a workout?
item.dc:creator: Juno DeMelo
item.media:credit: Caleb Thal for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About the New Covid Booster Shots
item.description: New shots targeting the latest version of the Omicron variant will be available soon. When should you get yours? Here’s what experts recommend.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new shots target the Omicron subvariant BA.5, the dominant version of the virus.

item.title: As Serena Williams Plays Her Final Matches, a Generation Is Inspired
item.description: Women across the country have seen their own lives reflected in the triumphs and trials of the tennis superstar. Cue the swell of emotion.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

item.title: Why We Get Motion Sick, and How to Stop It
item.description: Experts say prevention is the best cure.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Guillem Casasus; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: How to Stay Hydrated in a Heat Wave
item.description: Many countries across the globe are facing dangerously high temperatures. Here’s what to do to stay safe.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: How an Afghan Soccer Player Escaped the Taliban and Began a New Life
item.description: How an Afghan soccer player and her teammates fled their homes, outran a murderous regime and forged the uncertain beginnings of a new life.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
